docs.snippet: Google's $6 billion bid for Groupon, an online coupon start-up, is an aggressive move by the company to dominate local online advertising and help with its long-sought move into social networking.     Google has offered Groupon $5.3 billion, with ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google's $6 billion bid for Groupon, an online coupon start-up, is an aggressive move by the company to dominate local online advertising and help with its long-sought move into social networking. Google has offered Groupon $5.3 billion, with the promise of $700 million in performance bonuses for management, according to a person knowledgeable about the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Several people close to the deal said Groupon, which is based in Chicago, was expected to approve the acquisition and an agreement could be signed as early as this week.

headline.main: Google's Groupon Gambit

docs.abstract: Investors worry that $6 billion bid by Google to purchase Groupon, online coupon start-up, is high price to pay for company that has uneven track record in generating sales for merchants; acquisition, largest in Google's history, is aggressive move by company to dominate local online advertising, as well as step toward long-sought goal of social networking; charts; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Google has finally set a date - or at least a ballpark one - for its long-awaited foray into electronic books, Google Editions. The company will introduce Google Editions by the end of the year, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday night, a delay of several months from the original timeline. Google had said that the venture would be ready by the end of the summer.

docs.snippet: Chicago has been home to far bigger transactions than the one being discussed between Google and Groupon. But few, if any, have had as much riding on it for the city as this $6 billion deal does.     Groupon, a Chicago company coveted for its abil...
docs.lead_paragraph: Chicago has been home to far bigger transactions than the one being discussed between Google and Groupon. But few, if any, have had as much riding on it for the city as this $6 billion deal does. Groupon, a Chicago company coveted for its ability to mobilize millions of people online to buy local products, offers steep daily discounts to consumers on an array of products and services. If the Google-Groupon deal is completed, Groupon will be one of the country's biggest start-up success stories and one likely to spur a frenzy of new investment in Internet-based companies, including more in sometimes-overlooked Chicago.

headline.main: Groupon's Biggest Deal Could Transform City's Tech Start-Ups

docs.lead_paragraph: 11:37 p.m. | Updated Groupon has walked away from Google's $6 billion takeover offer, according to a person close to Groupon. The rejection at least temporarily thwarts Google's efforts to buy the social buying site, which would have been its largest acquisition to date. According to several people with knowledge of the takeover talks but who were not authorized to speak publicly on the matter, Google was eager to purchase the fast-growing start-up, based in Chicago, raising its bid at least once during negotiations.

headline.main: Groupon Said to Pass On Rich Bid From Google

docs.snippet: Most important, if your campaigns aren't going into the black after a lot of effort to make them work, don't keep spending money....
docs.lead_paragraph: A few days ago, I described how a stay-at-home mom named Amy Gottesman built a six-figure party-entertainment business largely via the effective use of Google AdWords and other pay-per-click advertising services. These services allow a company to bid on certain keywords and phrases, and if the bid is high enough a short ad from the company will appear alongside the search results of anyone typing those words into a search engine and on some other Web sites. The business then pays the bid price -- it can be anywhere from pennies to more than a thousand dollars depending on the competition for those words -- every time someone clicks on the ad.

headline.main: Seven Pay-Per-Click Mistakes to Avoid

docs.abstract: Most important, if your campaigns aren't going into the black after a lot of effort to make them work, don't keep spending money.

docs.snippet: As you may have noticed, we've been writing about Groupon a lot lately. MP Mueller did a post on the experiences of a high-end restaurant in Austin, Tex., and offered some tips. I suggested how you might do the math to assess your Groupon deal (an...
docs.lead_paragraph: As you may have noticed, we've been writing about Groupon a lot lately. MP Mueller did a post on the experiences of a high-end restaurant in Austin, Tex., and offered some tips. I suggested how you might do the math to assess your Groupon deal (and a smart reader pointed out that I did not fully account for the loss of revenue if your regular customers buy Groupon coupons). In fact, we got lots of smart comments (especially here and here). We also ran several articles when it looked as if Google was going to buy Groupon and another reporting that the founders and owners of Groupon had decided to turn down Google's $6 billion offer. Groupon is a remarkable idea that has been executed remarkably well, but is turning down $6 billion smart 0r insane? In all of our reporting, posting and commenting, we really didn't hear much from one group: the businesses who've used Groupon and were satisfied enough to use it again. Groupon says that more than 95 percent of its merchants want to run another discount. But a study out of Rice University suggests that only 58 percent of Groupon's merchants would want to do it again.

headline.main: Are You Happy With Groupon?

docs.abstract: You're the Boss column on whether businesses are happy with Groupon and satisfied enough to use it after initial discounts offered to customers (M)

docs.snippet: The 30-year-old chief executive of Groupon, Andrew Mason, is the newest member of tech's most exclusive club: entrepreneurs who walked away from multibillion-dollar takeover offers. On Friday, Mr. Mason rejected Google's $6 billion bid, according ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The 30-year-old chief executive of Groupon, Andrew Mason, is the newest member of tech's most exclusive club: entrepreneurs who walked away from multibillion-dollar takeover offers. On Friday, Mr. Mason rejected Google's $6 billion bid, according to two people with direct knowledge of the situation. The move quashed the search giant's hope of buying the fast-growing social buying site and put Groupon on track for an eventual public offering. Whether his gamble is a brilliant play or a Friendster fumble - the once promising social network that tumbled after snubbing an offer from Google - remains to be seen. For now, Mr. Mason, who is currently juggling television appearances and managing a recent spike in traffic, seems content with Groupon's trajectory. Mr. Mason spoke with DealBook on Wednesday about his company's prospects, the opportunities in the local advertising market, and why he likes dollhouses. Q.How was Friday? A.What happened on Friday? Haha Friday was a good day.

headline.main: DEALBOOK ONLINE: GROUPON'S FUTURE

docs.abstract: DealBook Online; Groupon chief executive Andrew Mason is said to have rejected Google's $6 billion bid; photo (S)

docs.snippet: Six years ago, after leaving a high-powered career in fashion sales to become a stay-at-home mother of very young children, Amy Gottesman found herself missing her income -- and looking for something to do when her kids were napping. So Ms. Gottes...
docs.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, after leaving a high-powered career in fashion sales to become a stay-at-home mother of very young children, Amy Gottesman found herself missing her income -- and looking for something to do when her kids were napping. So Ms. Gottesman, who lives on Long Island, put up a Web site under the name of Smash Party Entertainment, offering entertainment for parties, ranging from casinos to living Roman ''statues'' to murder mysteries. And then she waited for the business to come in -- which it didn't, even though she was advertising in local newspapers and mailing out coupons. After three months of staring at the phone, she decided to try $20 worth of pay-per-click advertising through Google's AdWords service, which placed her short ads alongside the search results for certain keywords, as well as on some Web pages with content related to those keywords. ''In a few days,'' she said, ''the phone started ringing.''

headline.main: An Online Strategy That Clicks

docs.abstract: You're the Boss blog on Amy Gottesman, owner of Smash Party Entertainment, who was having little luck with local ads but has brought in business using Google AdWords; photo (M)

docs.snippet: People going online to browse their virtual bookstore turn mostly to the leading search engine,  Google. In the four weeks ending Dec. 4, 51 percent  of those searching for the term ''ebook'' did so on Google, followed by Yahoo (28 percent) and Bi...
docs.lead_paragraph: People going online to browse their virtual bookstore turn mostly to the leading search engine, Google. In the four weeks ending Dec. 4, 51 percent of those searching for the term ''ebook'' did so on Google, followed by Yahoo (28 percent) and Bing (14 percent). This breakdown bodes well for the Google bookstore, Google.com/eBooks, which began on Dec. 6. Google shoppers can store their titles in an online library and read them on computers, smartphones, e-readers and the iPad.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 16, Google released the first version of its Body Browser, a simulation of the human body. Users can travel, as in the 1980s movie "Innerspace," through various layers of human anatomy, zooming in on internal organs, navigating around bones and peeling back layers of the human body until all that's left are the stringy tangles of the nervous system.

docs.snippet: On Dec. 16, Google released the first version of its Body Browser, a simulation of the human body. Users can travel, as in the 1980s movie ''Innerspace,'' through various layers of human anatomy, zooming in on internal organs, navigating around bo...
docs.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 16, Google released the first version of its Body Browser, a simulation of the human body. Users can travel, as in the 1980s movie ''Innerspace,'' through various layers of human anatomy, zooming in on internal organs, navigating around bones and peeling back layers of the human body until all that's left are the stringy tangles of the nervous system. The Body Browser works only in browsers that support WebGL, a new 3-D graphics tool that is appearing in the latest versions of popular browsers like Chrome 9 Beta from Google and Firefox 4 Beta. With WebGL, users do not need plug-ins like Flash or Java - the browser itself can handle complex graphics tasks.

headline.main: Body Browser Is a Google Earth for the Anatomy

docs.abstract: Gadgetwise blog notes Google releases first version of its Body Browser, simulation of human body; drawing (S)

docs.snippet: Last year, as 2009 came to a close, I wrote a blog post predicting that 2010 would be the ''Year of the Tablet.'' This was several months before the Apple iPad was announced by Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive.     I said then that 2010 wou...
docs.lead_paragraph: Last year, as 2009 came to a close, I wrote a blog post predicting that 2010 would be the ''Year of the Tablet.'' This was several months before the Apple iPad was announced by Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive. I said then that 2010 would bring a number of tablet computers to the market, including innovative products from Apple, Microsoft, Google and other PC manufacturers, that would change the face of computing and the way we consume magazines, newspapers, video and other Web content.

headline.main: Year of the Tablet, Take 2?

docs.abstract: Bits blog; popularity of Apple's iPad gives much-needed boost to tablet computer market; many technology pundits are predicting 2011 to be the year that devices grab hold of consumers' attention; many had forecast 2010 would be year tablets took off, but segment needed successful, innovative product like the iPad to get it going; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Thanks, everyone, for the comments on the last post, in whatever airport or train station the holidays found you....
docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks, everyone, for the comments on the last post, in whatever airport or train station the holidays found you. Pooks, referring to Moda Operandi, makes a good point about the difficulty of judging collections online ("those runway pieces can weigh a ton"), and I would add that the quality of fabrics may take a hit in the coming year or two as designers look for better-priced alternatives or cut corners. There has been a substantial increase in the cost of raw materials, especially cotton. And thanks to Kimb for information about getting the right fit online. Zachary: the folks at Google told me they want to do a boutiques.com for men but no timetable yet.

headline.main: Keeping Closer Tabs on Designers

docs.abstract: Thanks, everyone, for the comments on the last post, in whatever airport or train station the holidays found you.

docs.snippet: Facebook likes big numbers - it now has more than 500 million users, each one of whom can have as many as 5,000 friends. Yet as a privately held company, its ownership base must remain small, or it will have to disclose publicly its financial resu...
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook likes big numbers - it now has more than 500 million users, each one of whom can have as many as 5,000 friends. Yet as a privately held company, its ownership base must remain small, or it will have to disclose publicly its financial results. A surging shadow market in the privately held shares of Facebook is making such restraint difficult and could spur the company to go public - even as its executives try to tamp down speculation about an initial public offering - much as similar pressure helped push Microsoft and Google toward their own initial public offerings.

headline.main: Share Rules Could Push An Offering By Facebook

docs.abstract: Prospects for initial public offering by Facebook grow stronger as surging shadow market in privately held shares and growing user base is increasingly making it difficult for company to remain private; similar pressure helped push Microsoft and Google toward their own initial public offerings; Securities and Exchange Commission is reported to have asked for information on Facebook, as well as Twitter, Zynga and LinkedIn; exact focus of inquiry is unclear, but legal experts say agency is likely looking into established shareholder limits for private companies, which could force Facebook's hand; photo (M)
